full_text: 30. Are you entitled to return to country of issuance of your passport Yes No Travel document Yes No Or other document Yes No (If not, explain why) I can not return to Nicaragua at this time, not only becauseoof my age, but also because I do not have any other relatives in Nicaragua and the only family that I have is here in the U.S. and ismmy daugther and that is why I apply for asylum. 31. What do you think would happen to you if you returned? (Explain) I do not think that the sandinistas will dare to do anything against my life, but one thing that they will surely do, is the fact that they will send me to a separate place where all the oldepeople are for the rest of my life, and that is why T am here. 32. When you left your home country, to what country did you intend to go? To the Unite States of America. 33. Would you return to your home country? Yes No (Explain) I would not do that, because just like I already stated I will be alone in Nicaragua, since all my family is here, and that is why I will only be lonely there, and I do not want to die there, since it is a communist country and I am oppossed to that system. 34. Have you or any member of your immediate family ever belonged to any organization in your home country? Yes No. (If yes, provide the following information relating to each organization: Name of organization, dates of membership or affiliation, purpose of the organization, what, if any, were your official duties or responsibilities, and are you still an active member. (If not, explain) 35. Have you taken any action that you believe will result in persecution in your home country? Yes No (If yes, explain) Just the fact that I left the country is enough for the sandinistas to persecute, but in my case I guess that the sandinistas would not dare, but they will certainly put me away. 36. Have you ever been detained interrogated convicted and sentenced imprisoned in any country? Yes No (If yes, specify for each instance: what occurred and the circumstances, dates, location, duration of the detention or imprisonment, reason for the detention or conviction, what formal charges were placed against you, reason for the release, names and addresses of persons who could verify these statements. Attach documents referring to these incidents, if any). 37. If you base your claim for asylum on current conditions in your country, do these conditions affect your freedom more than the rest of that country's population? Yes No (If yes, explain) I guess they do, because my daughter had always been against the communist regime of Nicaragua and also I do not share the communists system that is at the present time in Nicaragua. 38. Have you, or any member of your immediate family, ever been mistreated by the authorities of your home country/country of nationality Yes No. If yes, was it mistreatment because of Race Religion Nationality Political opinion or Membership of a particular social group? Specify for each instance; what occurred and the circumstances, date, exact location, who took such action against you and what was his/her position in the government, reason why the incident occurred, names and addresses of people who witnessed these actions and who could verify these statements. Attach documents referring to these incidents. 39. After leaving your home country, have you traveled through (other than in transit) or resided in any other country before entering the U.S.? Yes No (If yes, identify each country, length of stay, purpose of stay, address, and reason for leaving, and whether you are entitled to return to that country for residence purposes. 40. Why did you continue traveling to the U.S.? I came here, to reunite with my relatives, and also looking for a safe haven, since Nicaragua is a communist country where nobody can live. 41. Did you apply for asylum in any other country? Yes-Give details No-Explain why not I did not apply anywhere else because my only family is here in the U.S.A. and fortthat reason I do not have anything to do anywhere else, also because I know that this is the safest country for the people escaping from the communism, which In a way I am. (3) (over)
